fields.description:
Note: This does not affect that much on small instance with less than 50 project. Typically large instances with > 500 projects might encountered the similar issue.

The project viewing page and browsing page, will by default have all the projects listed therefore it will request for all the project avatars from JIRA. 

From our test recently, we have found that 900 requests arrived for an instance with 700+ projects with unique project avatar of 200+. 

You can check the access logs for the request for the project avatar similar to something below:

{code}
127.0.0.1 127.0.0.1 - [11/Jun/2014:13:56:31 +0100] "GET /secure/projectavatar?pid=10000&avatarId=10000&size=small HTTP/1.0" 200 4026 2338 "https://example.atlassian.net/secure/project/ViewProjects.jspa" "Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:29.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/29.0"
{code}

This should not be an issue as this requests should be handled less within a second. However, it carries potential for the front end to be piled with requests when JIRA is busy, therefore causing some downtime if the buffer cannot handle the request further.

*Suggestion:*

* Pagination
* Handle the similar avatar requests as one single request
fields.summary: JIRA requests for Project Avatars Using Different URLs and Requests all in a Single Page load for View Project

fields.description:
In https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-32362 Eric Dalgliesh said: 
"This is the new stable filter behaviour and is deliberate." - but that is not a reason. It's very very annoying. (Also: what's the point of votes if you close legitimate issues?)

I work in a team, we all pick issues from a shared filter, when we start working on an issue we set it to "In progress" so it no longer matches the filter, when we finish working on an issue - we want to go back to the filter and pick the next issue in the list - but we have to remember to reload this page every time because of this annoying bug.

There are many ways it could be determined that the issue list is stale. In my case, we directly updated an issue from the list - that should be enough to trigger a refresh.
fields.summary: Issue list does not refresh when returning to an issue list

The DBCP pool-test-on-borrow parameter should explicitly be set to false on the dbconfig.xml file

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-38750].
  {panel}

The [Tuning Database Connections|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Tuning+Database+Connections] document states the following on the {{pool-test-on-borrow}} parameter:
{quote}
*Recommendation / Notes*
This value should always be 'false' as JIRA borrows a connection for each database operation.

(/) If you continue to have problems with database connections closing, try setting this option to 'true'. However, this should only be used as a last resort and only in the event that decreasing the value of *Time Between Eviction Runs* has not reduced or prevented problems with database connections closing.

*Default value*
false
(when not specified in dbconfig.xml)
{quote}

However, looking into the [Apache DBCP Documentation|http://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-dbcp/configuration.html], we can see that the default value for this option is *true*:
{quote}
|| Parameter || Default || Description ||
| (...) | (...) | (...) |
| testOnBorrow | true | The indication of whether objects will be validated before being borrowed from the pool. If the object fails to validate, it will be dropped from the pool, and we will attempt to borrow another.|
{quote}

This means that the validation query is executed *every time a connection is borrowed from the pool*.

I have confirmed this behaviour by enabling SQL logging on PostgreSQL and confirming the validation query was executed every time a query was triggered from JIRA. 

We should review our documents which provide a sample {{dbconfig.xml}} with a validation query, as this parameter (<pool-test-on-borrow>) should be explicitly declared as *false* in those examples:
- https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Connecting+JIRA+to+PostgreSQL
- https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Connecting+JIRA+to+SQL+Server+2008
- https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Connecting+JIRA+to+Oracle
- https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Connecting+JIRA+to+MySQL
- https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Surviving+Connection+Closures

I will also update the [Tuning Database Connections|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Tuning+Database+Connections] document to correct parameter value there.
fields.summary: Review all DB configuration documents regarding the Test On Borrow parameter

fields.description:
Can't resolve or close our own tickets... I'd mark this as invalid (can see wanting to know who ran the import tool, and it's very trivial to adjust on your own afterwards).

Mantis has a Date Submitted field that comes over to Created correct.
Mantis has a Reporter that comes over to Reporter correct.

However at the top of the activity field is a created issue that uses the name of user that ran the jira import tool.

Would kinda expect Reporter to match Creator on a bulk import. (update jiraissue set CREATOR = REPORTER)

There's a configurable permission to allow setting Reporter to someone else during issue creation (ie someone reporting an issue from someone else and doesn't care to track themselves.)

Creator is rarely exposed, except for top of activity > all.

JIRA 6.2.7 against Mantis 1.2.15
fields.summary: JIM Mantis Import Creator vs Reporter

fields.description: h4. Summary Ordinarily if you put a URL into any text field in a JIRA issue, the renderer will convert the URL into an actual hyperlink. If there are any non-latin characters, then this processing stops, and the URL only works up to that character. This affects any field. Here is a sample of the problem in various languages: !IDN links.png! See [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internationalized_domain_name] for details on IDN standards. h4. Steps to Reproduce # Create an issue # Insert a URL containing any non-latin character into any field # Observe the link only goes up to the last alphanumeric character before the non-latin character h4. Workaround This may work for the description field or any other that uses the wiki markup rendered: # Enable the "html" module in the "Wiki Renderer Macros Plugin" plugin # Use the html macro in the text area to manually create the link, for example: {code:none} {html}http://127.0.0.1/path/中国的{html} {code}
fields.summary: Automatic link from URL does not support IDN (non-latin character) URLs

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-38732].
  {panel}

jira.text.field.character.limit is respected for description, environment, comments.

However some add-ons could use a large custom field instead of their own database table to track things so having jira.text.field.character.limit affect custom fields by default is risky.

Propose new jira.text.field.character.limit.customfields (so it falls right next to existing) it should default to 0 as well.

Bonus: This way a jira-system-administrator can control it above a jira-administrator who may be making custom fields and not always understanding implications.

There is already a request for setting limits on a single custom field (especially at least at creation). vs Hack of of making a field a system field...
fields.summary: jira.text.field.character.limit.customfields

*Steps to Reproduce:*
# install JIRA wallboard plugin.
# got to the dashboard and click on the _Tools > View as Wallboard_.
# check the logs to find the following lines:
{code} 2014-06-12 21:58:30,345 http-bio-7625-exec-17 INFO admin 1318x143x1 vnimab 10.60.5.147 /plugins/servlet/Wallboard/ [atlassian.jirawallboard.servlet.WallboardServlet] Session id is: 0AAB676DD1908CEFC39253569A7C3593 {code}
# stop JIRA.
# Find the file in _JIRA Installation Folder > atlassian-jira > WEB-INF > classes > log4j.properties_.
# edit the file and add another logging properties inside for JIRA Wallboard plugin:
{code}
log4j.logger.com.atlassian.jirawallboard.servlet.WallboardServlet = WARN, console, filelog
log4j.additivity.com.atlassian.jirawallboard.servlet.WallboardServlet = false
{code}
# start JIRA and view the dashboard on wallboard again.

*Expected Result:*
Any logging below WARN will not be appearing on the logs.

*Actual Result:*
The INFO logs still appearing in the logs:
{code} 2014-06-12 21:58:30,345 http-bio-7625-exec-17 INFO admin 1318x143x1 vnimab 10.60.5.147 /plugins/servlet/Wallboard/ [atlassian.jirawallboard.servlet.WallboardServlet] Session id is: 0AAB676DD1908CEFC39253569A7C3593 {code}

*Note:*
* The logging will be possible to be set up only on UI (Logging and Profiling)
* After refresh, the logging level change back from WARN to ALL.

fields.description:
I created a numeric custom field and put the following values in it for some issues

10
8
0
-8
-10

The JQL failed to interpret negative numbers correctly but seems to work for positive ones

For example

project = X and numberfield > 5  (/)
project = X and numberfield < 5  (/)
project = X and numberfield > 0  (/)
project = X and numberfield < 0  (/)
project = X and numberfield < 0  (/)
project = X and numberfield < -0  (/)

project = X and numberfield > -20  (x)
project = X and numberfield < -5  (x)

It seems to lose its mind on negative number inputs in the JQL RHS

Quoting the strings does not help either eg project = X and numberfield > '-20'

Strangely project = X and numberfield > -0 works
fields.summary: JQL fails to search correctly on numeric fields when negatives are involved

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-38662].
  {panel}

After did some further investigation in https://support.atlassian.com/browse/JSP-193355 support request, it seem  our [Create a new issue or add a comment to an existing issue|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Creating+Issues+and+Comments+from+Email#CreatingIssuesandCommentsfromEmail-Createanewissueoraddacommenttoanexistingissue] article information is not complete.

Perhaps, we can include the following details:

{quote}
An email is classified as 'bulk' if any of the following is true:
* The first 'Precedence' header in the message is 'bulk'
* The message is a "multipart/report" message and the content type contains 'report-type=delivery-status'
* The message is not a "multipart/report" message and the "Return-Path" is "<>"
* The message contains the header "Auto-Submitted" with a value different than "no"

If an email is 'bulk', there are three possible actions:
* The mail is ignored, the debug log should have the line "Ignoring email with bulk delivery type", adds the log line 'Rejecting message due to failed bulk check.' and the issue/comment *is not* created.
* The mail is forwarded, the debug log should have the line "Forwarding email with bulk delivery type", adds the log line 'Rejecting message due to failed bulk check.' and the issue/comment *is not* created.
* The mail is deleted, the debug log should have the line "Deleting email with bulk delivery type", adds the log line 'Rejecting message due to failed bulk check.' and the issue/comment *is not* created.

If the email is 'bulk' but the MailHandler does not have a valid config for 'bulk=', it will be processed as any regular (i.e. non bulk) mail. Note: this assumption needs to be tested, the MailHandler might set a default 'bulk' value) 
{quote}

We think the doc need to add more information, as in it does not include the "multipart/report" cases, it does not mention that *not* configuring "bulk" will include those emails in the regular process (see note above) and does not makes it clear enough that configuring 'bulk' means those bulk emails will not create issues/comments.
fields.summary: Update Mail Handler Documentation

  {panel}

Dear Atlassian,

We were very upset to find out that after deleting a very large issue by accident we were unable to restore it.  All solutions provided on the forums were workarounds and that Jira itself was not designed to support "soft deletes". 

We feel that ticket information is very important.  Not only you lose the ticket and its history but also every work log entries of time tracking.  Since the data really belongs to us, the customer, we feel this is unacceptable.

We would appreciate if the Jira team corrects this design flaw and not closes it as done with similar issue: JRA-21831.

Thanks in advance,
Customer

fields.description:
When user search any issue from Issue Navigator, they can see the *Time waiting for support* and *Time to resolution* values as per [^issue-navi.png] screenshot.

Export issues to Excel also able to show the  *Time waiting for support* and *Time to resolution* values as per [^xls.png] screenshot.

However, the data is not shown in XML format as per [^xml2.png] screenshot.

*Finding:*
* ServiceDesk Add-on v1.2.6.1
* Locked Custom Fields ([^locked-vs-unlocked.png]) able to show the values in XML format if compare [^xml1.png] with [^xml2.png]
fields.summary: Service Desk SLA Custom Field values doesn't show in XML format

fields.description:
In status boxes, when status text is long, "text-overflow: ellipsis;" is applied.
This missalign the text, and multiple status boxes texts are not aligned vertically.

Everything in jira is left align and in tables, and suddenly, status are not perfectly aligned, this makes my eyes bleed.

As the status box size depends on text size (up to a limit), it doesn't matter if it's left of center, except for alignment.

JIRA v6.2.4, chorme 35.0.1916.114 m
fields.summary: css: .aui-lozenge text-align is center instead of left.

fields.description:
In Chrome browser, the date picker does not show default date correctly (should be today's date) when the user profile language is Japanese. The date picker works correctly in Firefox, Safari and Opera (not supported) browsers.

h3.How to reproduce
# Maintain JIRA date and time settings including advanced settings for the date/time picker to be default.
# Set the system/computer date to "5 June 2014"
# Set the profile language is English/German/France/Spanish.
# Create a new issue and select a date picker field like the due date. The correct date "05-06-2014" is chosen.
# Change the user profile language to Japanese.
# Create a new issue and select a date picker field like the due date. Now the date picker does not show the correct default date. The date shown is "06-05-2014" is chosen as default - maybe that the month and date gets mixed up.

h3.Screenshot
See attachment: "JRA-38643.png"

h3.Workaround
Use a different browser like Firefox or Safari which is also part of [Supported Platforms|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Supported+Platforms].
fields.summary: Date picker chooses incorrect default date in Chrome browser when user profile language is Japanese
This warning message isn't very accurate, and actually quite confusing
Open .doc files created via Issue Navigator export in Pages 5

fields.description:
h3. LDAP Connector:
1. Create new LDAP directory.
2. Click 'Save and Test'
3. On the next screen, click 'Edit Settings'
4. Change the username and password
5. Click 'Quick Test'
6. Click 'Save and Test'
7. click 'Edit Settings' again
8. 'Quick Test' fails

Looking at the 'ldap.password' value in cwd_directory_attribute table, the password from the initial account used to create the directory is intact.

From my testing, step 5, ie.'Quick Test' after changing credentials, is where we forget to store the new password in the database, since if you jump that step the password gets properly saved.

h3. Workaround for LDAP Connector
- Skip step 5.

h3. Delegated LDAP Connector
1. Create new delegated LDAP directory and save it
2. Edit the directory and update username and password
3. Click 'Test Settings' and then 'Save and Test'
4. 'Edit' the same connector and click 'Test Settings'. The test fails, as the new user and password was never saved to the database.

h3. Workaround for Delegated LDAP Connector
(!) Do not click the 'Test Settings' button
- Open console in the browsers developer tools and run the following commands
{code}
AJS.$('#configure-delegating-ldap-form-submit').removeAttr("aria-disabled");
AJS.$('#configure-delegating-ldap-form-submit').removeAttr("disabled");
{code}
- That will allow you to click the 'Save and Test' button, with first clicking 'Test Settings'
fields.summary: LDAP connector credentials not stored properly when editing user directory
Activity tab shows content with no clear relation to issue

fields.description:
A number of vulnerabilities have been identified in Tomcat 7.0.52:

h5. Low: Information Disclosure CVE-2014-0119

In limited circumstances it was possible for a malicious web application to replace the XML parsers used by Tomcat to process XSLTs for the default servlet, JSP documents, tag library descriptors (TLDs) and tag plugin configuration files. The injected XML parser(s) could then bypass the limits imposed on XML external entities and/or have visibility of the XML files processed for other web applications deployed on the same Tomcat instance.

h5. Important: Denial of Service CVE-2014-0075

It was possible to craft a malformed chunk size as part of a chucked request that enabled an unlimited amount of data to be streamed to the server, bypassing the various size limits enforced on a request. This enabled a denial of service attack.

h5. Important: Information disclosure CVE-2014-0096

The default servlet allows web applications to define (at multiple levels) an XSLT to be used to format a directory listing. When running under a security manager, the processing of these was not subject to the same constraints as the web application. This enabled a malicious web application to bypass the file access constraints imposed by the security manager via the use of external XML entities.

h5. Important: Information disclosure CVE-2014-0099

The code used to parse the request content length header did not check for overflow in the result. This exposed a request smuggling vulnerability when Tomcat was located behind a reverse proxy that correctly processed the content length header.

See http://tomcat.apache.org/security-7.html#Apache_Tomcat_7.x_vulnerabilities for links to more detailed descriptions.
fields.summary: Upgrade JIRA to the latest minor Tomcat (7.0.54+) to fix security vulnerabilites

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-38629].
  {panel}

h3. Current behaviour

When the user generates a support.zip file, he has to browse through the folder in order to get the file.

h3. Expected behaviour

It would be great to have a support.zip download link after generating the file.

Some users are JIRA administrators, but have no access to the JIRA server itself, which can make the troubleshooting process longer for support tickets.
fields.summary: Download link for support.zip after generation
